profileText: A Representative from Maryland; born on the family homestead, "Wetcpquin," Somerset County, Md., November 1, 1806; completed preparatory studies; was graduated from Washington Academy, Somerset County, where he became assistant tutor before his studies were completed; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Princess Anne, Somerset County, Md.; member of the State house of delegates in 1832, 1835, 1840, and 1866; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-seventh Congress (March 4, 1841-March 3, 1843); took an active part in the State constitutional conventions of 1864 and 1867; elected attorney general of the State in 1867; elected judge of the court of arbitration of Baltimore in 1877; director of the Maryland State School for the Deaf, Frederick, Md., 1867-1893 and of the Maryland School for the Colored Blind and Deaf at Baltimore 1872-1893; died in Baltimore, Md., July 5, 1893; interment in Greenmount Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1841, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: Letter of Issac Dashiell Jones from the United States House of Representatives concerning the tariff bill that had passed the House.

recordLocation.name: Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library

researchRecord.name: In Jones collection, 1729-1871, 1 box.
researchRecord.description: Collection is chiefly legal papers relating to land in Somerset and Worcester Counties, Maryland.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of A.E. Carroll,1822-1890.
In the W.W. Griest Collection of Lincolnia, 1857-1929, 3.5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes speech of Isaac D. Jones, Esq. of Somerset County delivered in the Constitutional Convention at Annapolis, Md., June 22, 1864, on the 23d Article of the Declaration of Rights.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of Thomas Hicks Wynne, 1820-1875, 2 microfilm reels.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Issac Dashiell Jones. Microfilm of originals at the Huntington Library, Manuscripts Department.

researchRecord.name: In the Quinby, Teackle, and Upshur family papers, 1759-1968, 2.8 feet.
